BE

..... In fact, I'll go back to that Deutsche one on interest rate sensitivities .....

BE

 The 1994 rate hike took investors by surprise with respect to timing
and magnitude. This triggered a significant spike in volatility,
accompanied by a sharp bond market sell-off. Capital markets banks’
performance suffered notably.
 The 2004 rate hike was followed by the Great Moderation, or a period
of declining volatility and rising asset prices. USD earners such as the
French or UK international banks outperformed. By contrast, the
Spanish international banks underperformed, due to their emerging
markets exposures. Meanwhile, the domestically-focused UK and
Spanish banks performed in line.

BE

......so ..........

11:20 am
BE

BE

Our rates and derivatives colleagues expect 100bps cumulative rate hikes by
2016, including 25bps liftoff this month, thereby more hawkish than current
market pricing and closer to Fed dots. Moreover, they forecast 10-year US
Treasuries to raise to 2.5% until year-end 2016 but acknowledge upside risks
to their forecasts, expect a widening of credit spreads in investment grade (by
10bps) and in high yield (by 100bps) and elevated but no extreme US equity
volatility.

BE

The interest rate sensitivity of the European banks in our coverage to US rates
largely depends on the geographic footprint (US and countries with USD-linked
exchange rates). UBS, Credit Suisse, HSBC and Standard Chartered are likely
to have the highest interest rate sensitivity in our coverage. Investment banks
are indirectly exposed to interest rates, largely via potentially higher customer
activity in the global Macro business (namely Rates and FX).
Generally banks are more exposed to the shorter-end of the yield curve
therefore disproportionately benefit from a bear flattening (short end led). US
curves have already been trending this way with our rates colleagues
expecting a much more pronounced flattening by 2016 with c.100bps uplift at
the short end and only a modest c.20bps increase at the long end.

11:21 am
BE

As for that Caz note (Caz being the underwriter on StanChart's cash call ...)

BE

BE

Or in text form .....

11:22 am
BE

 NPL sensitivity analysis shows capital cushion: We forecast StanChart’s
NPL and coverage ratio to rise to 3.9% and 62%, respectively, by FY16E
from 2.6% and 52% at FY14. As sensitivity, every 1% higher NPL ratio
reduces the CET1 ratio by c40bps assuming coverage at 62%. We forecast
2016 CT1 at 14.1%, implying that a scenario where NPL ratio & coverage
go to the 1990s EM cycle peak would still result in CT1 above 12%.
 Strategic actions: Management actions to improve ROE, reposition capital
allocation and risk will take time to bear fruit. Key highlights 1) Cost saves
target of $2.9bn with net costs down in 2018 on 2015, including additional
$1bn investment into 4 areas: Retail, Private banking, Africa and RMB
services. 2) $100bn RWA restructuring (one-third of group) to reposition
ROE profile and risk, which is split $50bn RWA in CIC/Commercial where
the group will aim to improve returns or exit, $30bn specific focus countries
where the group will restructure while retaining options to explore
alternatives, $20bn RWA outside risk tolerance to be liquidated and $5bn
peripheral businesses to be exited. 3) Restructuring costs of $3bn (incl.
goodwill) with only a small impact on CT1 due to the RWA offset.
 Normalised ROTE has upside: Management’s RoE illustration of 8%-10%
for 2018/20E allows for material regulatory headwinds, with potential 1-2%
incremental tailwind from higher US rates and normalization of the UK
bank levy, in our view. We currently forecast 9.8% RoTE in FY18E with
potential for 1.8% upside in ROTE from US rates and a normalised bank
levy which falls away from 2021

BE

I wish there were more to say than that. But there isn't.

11:24 am
PM

So finally the Fed got their ‘a into g’. But before I explain how they have left it far too late
to tighten and avoid another meltdown in the global financial system, I want to have a word
about our impending January 12 Global Strategy Conference. We are really pleased to have
Russell Napier as our guest speaker this year. He is both a stockmarket historian and a
specialist in emerging markets. As China begins the devaluation we have long been warning
of, Russell is the man you want to hear for how 2016 will likely see the global economy sink
both below the water-line. We now have almost 800 acceptances and space in the venue is
getting a tad tight. So if you haven’t replied but want to experience an early 2016 shiver of
fear (reality?) to give you head-start to what is likely to be a very turbulent 2016, please click
on the banner above and fill in your details, or indeed just e-mail me. Advert over!

PM

January 12 for your diary

PM

In the wake of the 2001 recession, an extended period of corporate de-leveraging to
unwind the excess of the tech bubble led the Fed to maintain loose monetary policy for far
too long. By the time it eventually began to tighten, in June 2004, household debt growth
was rampant and eventually blew up the economy. This time around it will be no different,
except credit growth has already reached peak historical rates. In short Janet It’s too late!

11:30 am
BE

Christmas shopping is in full swing: November retails sales volumes (excl auto) increased by 1.7% mom and 3.9% yoy, significantly above consensus estimates of 0.5% and 2.2%, respectively. Retail sales volumes including auto fuel increased by 5.0% yoy and 1.7% mom. Today’s data exceeded even our own long-held bullish view on UK retail. For the 17th month in a row, store prices declined (3.3% yoy). Nevertheless, the value of goods bought (incl fuel) increased by 1.4% over the same period. In the first three quarters of the year nominal GDP expanded at an average rate of 2.5% yoy. Retail sales (excl auto) have expanded by an average rate of 4.4% per month over the same period. While construction and manufacturing show some weakness and in the face of heightened international risks, the domestic economy is picking up the slack and delivering solid growth. But, history shows that when an unbalanced expansion goes on unchecked for too long (think 2008) it can prove to be unsustainable.

BE

Is domestic demand gathering too much momentum too quickly? An important trend is emerging. Yesterday’s labour market data continued a several months long trend of unemployment coming in below estimates (5.2% versus a consensus of 5.3%). Retail sales have followed a similar trend in the second half of the year (see Chart 1). Add to this mix the persistently strong growth in UK house prices and consumer credit growing at decade highs and it is becoming increasingly clear that domestic demand is becoming frothy. For the sake of sustaining healthy growth, the Bank of England should be strongly considering interest rate rises. The MPC’s concerns about foreign risks, strong sterling and a potential softening in wage growth all warrant caution. But unlike the financial crisis, which needed an emergency monetary response, these risks do not. Whilst still remaining accommodative, modestly higher rates would help to stave off some of the excess momentum in domestic demand. However, the MPC are clearly compelled to act cautiously in the face of current weak inflation which runs the risk of mistiming the first hike.

BE

Retrophin filed a federal lawsuit against Shkreli on Monday in New York alleging that he created the biotech and took it public solely to provide stock to MSMB investors when the hedge fund became insolvent. The suit seeks more than $65 million in damages and a requirement that Shkreli disgorge all the compensation he received from Retrophin during the time he acted as a “faithless servant” to it, as the claim reads. Turing Pharmaceuticals, another biotech startup that Shkreli founded this past February, is not named in the suit.

BE

BE

Here's Berenberg.

BE

● Since our initiation in March 2015, Pets at Home’s share price has
increased by 19%, outperforming the FTSE 250 by 21%, as the business has
continued to deliver on its roll-out of stores, vet practices and groomers.
However, FY 2016 has been a tough year so far, with various factors
contributing to a slowdown in like-for-like sales growth. With
management tempering expectations for the full-year and with margins
expected to be squeezed in FY 2017 by increased investment in the retail
business, we downgrade to Hold and reduce our price target to 305p. We
continue to prefer veterinary consolidator CVS (Buy, price target 880p) in
the UK pet market.

11:41 am
BE

● Accessories will recover but not this year: Like-for-like sales growth in
Pets at Home’s retail business slowed to 1% in H1 2016, driven by tough
comparables, a poor flea season and customers purchasing at lower price
points in some categories. While these issues should abate, we think there
is little near-term potential for upside to consensus expectations for FY
2016-17, which would be a catalyst for the share price to re-rate further.
● Margins squeezed by seamless shopping and living wage: Management
has highlighted that increased investment will be required in the
company’s “seamless shopping” experience, spanning both the online and
retail businesses. Furthermore, it expects a £2m impact on operating costs
from the introduction of the living wage, further affecting margins.
Combined, these are expected to dilute EBITDA margins by 10-20bp in FY
2017, with our forecast EBITDA margin falling from 16.4% to 16.1% 2015A-
2017E, before beginning to recover.

BE

● Longer-term opportunity remains: Our thesis on Pets at Home focuses on
the importance of the services business in driving sustainable sales growth
and margin expansion. We continue to see upside from the roll-out of vets
and groomers. In the near-term, however, we believe the investment
required in the retail business offsets the benefit of this roll-out, making
the investment case less compelling for now. We will revisit the shares
once the impact of this investment is clear and a path to margin expansion
is visible.
● Catalysts: Pets at Home has a Q3 trading update on 20 January.
● Valuation: Pets at Home now trades at 17.6x 2017E P/E versus specialist
retail peers at 13.4x. While we continue to believe Pets at Home should
trade at a premium to peers, we believe the current c4x premium
represents fair value for the business.

BE

Which is all pretty straightforward, if you believe 2015 was a weak year for Pets because of a flea shortage.

Entertainment One Ltd (ETO:LSE): Last: 179.02, up 8.32 (+4.87%), High: 182.40, Low: 174.50, Volume: 395.36k
BE

Here's RBC.

BE

Extends strategic film output deal with DreamWorks Pictures. eOne announced that it has extended its output agreement with DreamWorks Pictures
through the creation of a new multi-year partnership. The company, in association with Steven Spielberg, Principal Partner, DreamWorks Studios; Jeff Skoll,
Chairman, Participant Media; and Anil Ambani, Chairman, Reliance Group; has formed Amblin Partners, a new film, television and digital content creation
company. The new partnership will see eOne expand its film distribution relationship with DreamWorks across additional territories and extend the collaboration
into television production and distribution as well as licensing and merchandising. eOne will handle distribution of Amblin Partners’ films on a multi-territory
output basis, adding Australia/New Zealand and Spain to its existing output deal with DreamWorks in the United Kingdom and the Benelux (which was due to
expire in 2016). Universal Pictures will distribute the partnership’s films in North America and other markets following the expiry of DreamWorks' agreement with
Disney next August. As part of the deal eOne will hold a small equity stake in Amblin Partners.
Amblin Partners will create content using the Amblin, DreamWorks Pictures and Participant brands. It will be led by CEO, Michael Wright, and President and
COO, Jeff Small. In addition, Amblin Television will become a division of Amblin Partners. Film projects in various stages of production include: The BFG, The
Light Between Oceans, and The Girl on the Train (all scheduled for 2016), as well as A Dog’s Purpose, and Ready Player One (2017). Upcoming shows from
Amblin TV include All the Way (HBO movie directed by Jay Roach and starring Bryan Cranston), and American Gothic, a summer series that will air on CBS. In
an interview with The New York Times, Mr. Spielberg (68) said much of his output as a director and producer would be placed under the umbrella of Amblin
Partners.  
Not financially material short-term, but strategically positive for eOne. The new company (Amblin Partners) will be backed by a US$500MM loan.
According to various media reports (WSJ, Bloomberg), the new venture will also get close to US$300MM in equity from its partners, including ~US$200MM from
Participant Media and another ~US$100MM in total from Reliance Entertainment, eOne, and Mr. Spielberg himself. We believe the financial impact of the
agreement is not immediately material for eOne, nor does it change the company’s outlook for F2016E. However, we view the deal as strategically positive,
extending and expanding an important film output deal with DreamWorks into new territories, as well as television and potentially M&L. While eOne’s equity
interest in the new partnership is likely very small (we would guess less than 5% although figures have not been disclosed), it gives eOne a “seat at the table” 
as Amblin Partners builds its film and television slate. Importantly, the agreement is very consistent with eOne’s well-articulated strategy to partner with the
world’s leading creative talent for production and distribution of the highest quality content.

PM

Here's some grey from a few days ago

11:55 am
PM

JPM

PM

Joyce Change

PM

Mauricio Macri will take office as president of Argentina on December 10, 2015, ending 12 years of Kirchnerism, with expectations running high that his victory is an inflection point for more orthodox and sustainable macroeconomic policies. Macri won the November 22 election by a solid margin, endorsing the message that the population favors wide-reaching change. Macri campaigned on a market-friendly platform that advocated major macroeconomic policy shifts. During his campaign, he embraced several macro reforms, including unifying the FX market, lifting capital controls, engaging in negotiations with holdout creditors, normalizing utility tariffs, introducing tax cuts to boost investment and employment, reducing trade barriers, and normalizing the reporting of economic statistics.

11:56 am
PM

Expectations for a policy shift are running high, while the cost of post-election monetary equilibrium is rising. The central bank’s liquidity position has deteriorated and reserves have fallen ahead of the expected liberalization of the FX market. Rebalancing the monetary and fiscal equilibrium to support growth in the medium term will require that the economy undergo a significant FX devaluation that could push the economy back to recession over the short term. The main challenge lies in Macri’s political capacity to speed up economic reforms without severely diluting his political capital and preserving governability. We anticipate a bumpy political and economic transition, but we believe Macri will wield a certain degree of influence to implement policy adjustments, at least in the first months of his administration.

PM

Argentine equity markets have underperformed, as investors likely anticipate ARS devaluation. Stocks have fallen by 8.9% in USD terms since the November 22 elections. Telecom Argentina and YPF are among the biggest losers in the equity markets, and we believe that highly distorted sectors such as utilities and agriculture will present better opportunities. We highlight Adecoagro (OW) in the capital goods & agribusiness sector and Endesa Chile (OW) in the utilities sector, which has relevant exposure to Argentina. In our view, Argentine external debt offers better opportunities, as the average spread of 636bp is among the highest of the major country segments in Latin America except for Brazil. We are Marketweight (MW) Argentina sovereign and corporate bonds, but we see opportunities in select names, with Overweight (OW) recommendations on Edenor, Cablevision, and IRSA Commercial Properties. The City and Province of Buenos Aires will be governed by the same party as the incoming president, which should help support the bonds from these regional governments.

PM

Stagflation in the short term is the price to pay for policy adjustments. The needed fiscal consolidation and FX devaluation are likely to have a large and immediate negative impact on consumption, while policy actions that boost investment and economic efficiency should take time to bear fruit. Accordingly, we forecast that the economy will fall back into recession in 1H16. We expect FX devaluation to be accompanied by monetary tightening to contain inflation expectations and to keep FX pass-through modest. Still, we see inflation surging to 35% early in 2016 from 25% in 2015 and then gradually falling back to 30% by end-2016. While a growth recovery is expected to take hold before year-end, the global backdrop of low commodity prices and weak regional demand is likely to weigh on Argentina’s rebound. That said, we expect Argentina’s activity to start recovering in 2H16, but not powerfully enough to allow for the economy to escape a recession next year; we forecast a 0.5% contraction in full-year genuine GDP. The main issue, in our view, is whether this backdrop will undermine Macri’s ability to deliver reform and preserve his control of government.

Timing of FX liberalization remains uncertain. After winning the November 22 election, Macri reiterated that he will unify the FX market and remove capital controls in the early days of his administration. However, future Finance Minister Alfonso Prat Gay announced that a single exchange-rate regime could take place on December 14, but that capital controls will be lifted only “when necessary conditions are met.” In our view, conditions will be determined by the government’s capacity to rebuild FX reserves in the short term. Initially, keeping capital controls in place and hiking interest rates sharply, while rebuilding reserves, in our view, will help to reduce the knee-jerk risk of the exchange rate overshooting to the downside, suggesting convergence to the current parallel FX rate of about 14.7 pesos per US dollar. However, this would be a short-term equilibrium given that as long as capital controls remain in place, a parallel FX rate should eventually emerge. We expect capital controls to be gradually removed early next year, with the USD/ARS rate weakening to 15.5 in 1Q16, and look for consistent monetary equilibrium, coupled with a more credible policy framework, to support USD/ARS stabilization at about 14.50 in 2H16. V. Werning and I. Cabiedes
